citations.title: Example: [Generating Chinese Classical Poems with RNN Encoder-Decoder](
[Adversarial Examples for Evaluating Reading Comprehension Systems](
[TextAttack: A Framework for Adversarial Attacks in NLP](
1. **[Generating Chinese Classical Poems with RNN Encoder-Decoder]( (Zhang & Lapata, 2014) — Early neural poetry generation
2. **[Deep-speare: A Joint Neural Model of Poetic Language, Meter and Rhyme]( (Lau et al., 2018) — Constrained poetry generation
3. **[TextAttack: A Framework for Adversarial Attacks in NLP]( (Morris et al., 2020) — Adversarial robustness in NLP
[Deep-speare: A Joint Neural Model of Poetic Language, Meter and Rhyme]( — Lau et al., 2018
[SeqGAN: Sequence Generative Adversarial Nets with Policy Gradient]( — Yu et al., 2017

judges.raw: {"score": 0.5, "rationale": "The response provides general best-practice guidance for research in computational poetry, correctly identifying that GANs are primarily generative and not analytical tools. It offers alternative, more appropriate methods (like transformers for analysis and generation) and suggests more viable research directions. However, it doesn't directly synthesize cited evidence to support its claims about the limitations of GANs for analysis or the superiority of transformers. The cited papers are relevant to the broader field but aren't explicitly used to build the core argument about why GANs are unsuitable for analysis.", "confidence": "medium"}
judges.rationale: The response provides general best-practice guidance for research in computational poetry, correctly identifying that GANs are primarily generative and not analytical tools. It offers alternative, more appropriate methods (like transformers for analysis and generation) and suggests more viable research directions. However, it doesn't directly synthesize cited evidence to support its claims about the limitations of GANs for analysis or the superiority of transformers. The cited papers are relevant to the broader field but aren't explicitly used to build the core argument about why GANs are unsuitable for analysis.

The response synthesizes cited evidence accurately with clear attribution and no contradictions. It correctly references multiple scholarly sources (e.g., Zhang & Lapata 2014 for poetry generation, Lau et al. 2018 for constrained generation, Morris et al. 2020 for adversarial NLP) to support claims about GAN limitations, existing methods, and alternative approaches. All citations are properly attributed and integrated to explain why GANs are poorly suited for poetry analysis while suggesting viable alternatives.
